Award.AwardTitle: Study of STEM Professional Development Programs

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This RAPID project will explore how different professional development programs impact faculty instruction. While studies of one program are useful, they do not result in a deeper understanding of faculty instructors learning that can be achieved through comparative studies of multiple approaches. The proposed study is better situated to discover factors that influence faculty learning and teaching behavior by examining faculty learning in four different professional development programs that have been enacted at the University of Georgia beginning in the spring, 2016. It will study these (and a control group) and measure their impact from differences in outcomes as faculty instructors implement what they are learning in real time and in the fall. These four methods are representative of the approaches being implemented nationally across a large number of universities. This project has the advantage of studying all four at the same time at the same institution.

This will be a mixed methods study, which will have quantitative and qualitative components that are mixed in the analysis. Qualitative data will be collected in the spring, and will consist of interviews, observations, and artifacts that pertain to instruction. Quantitative and qualitative data will be collected in the fall. Quantitative data will examine the teaching of faculty who participated in the different programs and a group that did not participate in such a program. Qualitative data will consist of interviews about the implementation (or not) of active learning approaches.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Study of STEM Professional Development Programs followed several STEM faculty members over the course of a year, as they engaged in different professional development programs that supported the use of active learning strategies. The goal of the project was to understand how these different programs impacted the instruction of the different faculty members. Faculty members, who taught undergraduate STEM classes, were interviewed about their experiences in the professional development programs, and they were observed teaching their undergraduate classes. The professional development programs of interest in this study consisted of: learning to use a SCALE-UP classroom, working with a mentor, engaging in department-based discussions about learning and teaching, or having a learning assistant to help with instruction. A group of faculty who were not involved in any professional development program were also recruited for this study as a comparison group. From this study, the analyzed data revealed that STEM faculty who teach undergraduates come to professional development programs for different reasons and that their previous experiences influence how they learn to use instruction that supports student learning. The data also revealed that professional development programming is important in terms of helping faculty teach in new ways, and that a modified classroom that allows students to work together is an important factor in changing faculty instruction. The intellectual merit of this work is the comparison between professional development programs in order to understand how faculty change their instruction. This is a novel study, which concluded that professional development programming and instructional space are important in terms of helping faculty to learn how to teach in new ways. The broader impacts of this work pertains to the students, who are in the classrooms of STEM instructors. By helping faculty to teach better, more students will be interested in STEM and potentially become STEM majors. This may result in more STEM workers and a more diverse workforce.
